COMMERCE.Parliament Mansions,Victoria Street, S.W.I.19th July, 1920.Sir,I have the honour by direction of the President and Council of this Association to transmit to you the terms of the following resolution unanimously adopted at the meeting of the Executive Council held at the Savoy Hotel this morningTho Council of the Association of 3ritish Chambers of ' Commerce direct public attention to the following facts:-(a) THAT the Railways owing to the increases in wages, cost of coal, materials, equipment and repairs are now being run at a loss to the taxpayer of one million sterling per week.' ', i'- is,(b) THAT delay in raising the goods rates and passenger fares to cover the cost of carrying goods and passengers respectively will cause increases in National Expenditure described in Budget taxation under the heading of Civil Service Estimates.-.V(c) THIS Council, while conscious of the inability of the State to run successfully and economically either the railways or any other industry, therefore respectfully offers Its support to the Government in it3 well justified attempt to make the railways self-supporting.I have the honour to be, Sir,Your obedient Servant,(Signed) B. B. DUNWOODY. Rt. Hon. Secretary.Austen Chamberlain, M.P,Chancellor of the Exchequer, The Treasury , S.'.\7.1.\
